discussion.p: Instantiating reference_wrapper<A> will instantiate the declarations of the hidden friends, which will attempt to determine the return types of the operator<=> functions. That fails because `synth-three-way` is constrained and can't be called with arguments of type `A`.

In practice the requires-clause can be implemented more simply (and efficiently) by checking the constraints of synth-three-way directly: requires (const T t) { { t < t } -> boolean-testable; }
but when specified in prose in a Constraints: element it seems clearer to just use synth-three-way(x.get(), y.get()).
The proposed resolution has been committed to libstdc++'s master branch.

pre.code: friend constexpr synth-three-way-result<T>auto operator<=>(reference_wrapper x, reference_wrapper y);

p.ins: -?- Constraints: The expression synth-three-way(x.get(), y.get()) is well-formed.

pre.code: friend constexpr synth-three-way-result<T>auto operator<=>(reference_wrapper x, const T& y);

p.ins: -?- Constraints: The expression synth-three-way(x.get(), y) is well-formed.

pre.code: friend constexpr synth-three-way-result<T>auto operator<=>(reference_wrapper x, reference_wrapper<const T> y);

blockquote.p:
-9- Constraints: is_const_v<T> is `false`.
The expression synth-three-way(x.get(), y) is well-formed.
